sen.j: 於大の方（おだいのかた、享禄元年（1528年） - 慶長7年8月28日 (旧暦)（1602年10月13日））は初め松平広忠正室、のちに久松俊勝夫人。
sen.e: Odainokata (1528-October 13, 1602) was the legitimate wife of Hirotada MATSUDAIRA, later became the wife of Toshikatsu HISAMATSU.
Odainokata (1528 - October 13, 1602) was the legitimate wife of Hirotada MATSUDAIRA, and later became the wife of Toshikatsu HISAMATSU.
Odainokata (1528 - October 13, 1602) was the legitimate wife of Hirotada MATSUDAIRA, and later became the wife of Toshikatsu HISAMATSU.

sen.j: 徳川家康の母として有名。
sen.e: She was famous as the mother of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
She was famous as the mother of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
She was famous as the mother of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 晩年は「伝通院」と称した。
sen.e: She called herself 'Denzyuin' in her last years.
She called herself 'Denzyuin' in her last years.
She called herself 'Denzuin' in her last years.

sen.j: なお、「於大」は後年の創作であって、実名は不詳である。
sen.e: She was called 'Odai' in future ages and her real name was unknown.
The name 'Odai' by subsequent generations, and her real name is unknown.
The name 'Odai' by subsequent generations, and her real name is unknown.

sen.j: なお、嘉永3年（1850年）10月29日に従一位の贈位があり、その位記では、諱を大子としている。
sen.e: On October 29, 1850, she was conferred the junior grade of the first court rank and her imina (real name) was Ogo in the court rank diploma.

On October 29, 1850, she was conferred the junior grade of the first court rank and her imina (personal name that was generally used posthumously or by one's parents or lord) was Ogo in the court rank diploma.
sen.cmt: real name > personal name that was generally used posthumously or by one's parents or lord
sen.e: On October 29, 1850, she was conferred Juichii (Junior First Rank) and her imina (personal name that was generally used posthumously or by one's parents or lord) was Ogo in the court rank diploma.

sen.j: 於大は尾張国知多郡の豪族水野忠政とその夫人華陽院の間に、父・忠政の居城緒川城（愛知県知多郡東浦町緒川）で生まれた。
sen.e: Odai was born as a daughter of a wealthy farmer of Chita district, Owari Province, Tadamasa MIZUNO, and his wife, Keyoin, in Ogawa-jo Castle of their father, Tadamasa.
Odai was born into a wealthy family as the daughter Tadamasa MIZUNO and his wife Keyoin at her father's Ogawa-jo Castle in Chita District, Owari Province.

Odai was born into a wealthy family as the daughter Tadamasa MIZUNO and his wife Keyoin at her father's Ogawa-jo Castle in Chita District, Owari Province (Ogawa, Higashiura-cho, Chita County, Aichi Prefecture).

sen.j: （青山政信の娘で忠政の養女であったという説あり）
sen.e: (It is said that she was a daughter of Masanobu AOYAMA and a foster daughter of Tadamasa.)
There is also a theory that she was a daughter of Masanobu AOYAMA and a foster daughter of Tadamasa.
sen.cmt: Rewritten to reflect source text.Deleted parentheses according to English conventions.
sen.e: There is also a theory that she was a daughter of Masanobu AOYAMA and a foster daughter of Tadamasa.

sen.j: 父・忠政は緒川からほど近い三河国にも所領を持っており、当時三河で勢力を振るっていた松平清康の求めに応じて於富の方を離縁して清康に嫁がせたが、松平氏とさらに友好関係を深めようと考え、天文10年（1541年）に娘の於大を清康の後を継いだ松平広忠に嫁がせた。
sen.e: Her father Tadamasa had also a territory in Mikawa Province near Ogawa, he made Otomi no kata divorce and made her marry Kiyoyasu by a request of Kiyoyasu MATUDAIRA who wielded much power in Mikawa at that time, and he wanted to strengthen the relationship with the MATSUDAIRA clan and married off his daughter Odai to Hirotada MATSUDAIRA who succeeded Kiyoyasu in 1541.

Her father Tadamasa also held a territory in Mikawa Province near Ogawa, and upon the request of Kiyoyasu MATSUDAIRA who held a great deal of power in Mikawa at the time, he made Otomi no Kata divorce and marry Kiyoyasu but his desire to further strengthen his relationship with the Matsudaira clan led him to marry off his daughter Odai in 1541 to Hirotada MATSUDAIRA who succeeded Kiyoyasu.

Her father Tadamasa also held a territory in Mikawa Province near Ogawa, and upon the request of Kiyoyasu MATSUDAIRA who held a great deal of power in Mikawa at the time, he made Otomi no Kata divorce and marry Kiyoyasu but his desire to further strengthen his relationship with the Matsudaira clan led him to marry off his daughter Odai in 1541 to Hirotada MATSUDAIRA who succeeded Kiyoyasu.

sen.j: 翌・天文11年12月26日（西暦1543年1月31日）、於大は広忠の長男竹千代（のちの徳川家康）を生む。
sen.e: On January 31, 1543, Odai gave birth to the first son Takechiyo (later Ieyasu TOKUGAWA).
On January 31, 1543, Odai gave birth to their first son Takechiyo (later Ieyasu TOKUGAWA).
On January 31, 1543, Odai gave birth to their first son Takechiyo (later Ieyasu TOKUGAWA).

sen.j: しかし忠政の死後水野氏を継いだ於大の兄水野信元が1544年に松平家の主君今川氏と絶縁して織田氏に従ったため、於大は今川家との関係を慮った広忠により離縁され、実家水野家の・三河国刈谷城（刈谷市）に返された。
sen.e: However, the Odai's brother Nobumoto MIZUNO who succeeded the Mizuno clan after the death of Tadamasa broke relations with the Imagawa family who was the master of the Matsudaira family in 1544, Odai was divorced by Hirotada who worried about relations with the Imagawa family and returned to Kariya-jo Castle (Kariya City) of the Mizuno family in Mikawa Province.

However, the Odai's brother Nobumoto MIZUNO who succeeded the Mizuno clan after the death of Tadamasa broke relations with the Imagawa family who was the master of the Matsudaira family in 1544, Odai was divorced by Hirotada who worried about relations with the Imagawa family and returned to Kariya-jo Castle (Kariya City) of the Mizuno family in Mikawa Province.

However, the Odai's older brother Nobumoto MIZUNO who succeeded the Mizuno clan after the death of Tadamasa broke relations with the Imagawa clan who was the master of the Matsudaira family and followed Oda clan in 1544, Odai was divorced by Hirotada who worried about relations with the Imagawa family and returned to Kariya-jo Castle (Kariya City) of the Mizuno family in Mikawa Province.

sen.j: 於大は1547年には信元の意向で知多郡阿古居城（阿久比町）の城主・久松俊勝に再嫁する。
sen.e: In 1547, Odai remarried Toshikatsu HISAMATSU, the lord of Agoya-jo Castle (Agui-machi) in Chita-gun according to the wish of Nobumoto.
In 1547, Odai remarried Toshikatsu HISAMATSU, the lord of Agoya-jo Castle (Agui-machi) in Chita-gun according to the wish of Nobumoto.
In 1547, Odai remarried Toshikatsu HISAMATSU, the lord of Agoya-jo Castle (Agui-machi) in Chita-gun according to the wish of Nobumoto.

sen.j: 俊勝は元々水野氏の女性を妻に迎えていたが、その妻の死後に水野家と松平家の間で帰趨が定まらず、松平氏との対抗上その関係強化が理由と考えられる。
sen.e: Toshimasa had married a daughter of the Mizuno family, but did not have good relationship with the Mizuno family or the Matsudaira family after her death, and he strengthened relations with the Mizuno family in his struggle against the Matsudaira family.

Toshimasa had married a daughter of the Mizuno family, but did not have good relationship with the Mizuno family or the Matsudaira family after her death, and he strengthened relations with the Mizuno family in his struggle against the Matsudaira family.

Toshimasa had married a daughter of the Mizuno clan, but did not have good relationship with the Mizuno family or the Matsudaira family after her death, and he strengthened relations with the Mizuno clan in his struggle against the Matsudaira family.

sen.j: 俊勝との間には三男三女をもうける。
sen.e: She bore Toshikatsu three sons and three daughters.
She bore Toshikatsu three sons and three daughters.
She bore Toshikatsu three sons and three daughters.

sen.j: この間、家康と音信を絶えず取り続けた。
sen.e: She kept up a regular correspondence with Ieyasu during this time.
She maintained regular correspondence with Ieyasu during this time.
She maintained regular correspondence with Ieyasu during this time.

sen.j: 桶狭間の戦いの後、今川家から自立し織田家と同盟した家康は、久松俊勝と於大の三人の息子に松平姓を与えて家臣とし、於大を母として迎えた。
sen.e: After the Battle of Okehazama, Ieyasu became independent of the Imagawa family and made an ally with the Oda family, gave the family name Matsudaira to the three sons of Toshikatsu HISAMATSU and Odai and made them his retainers, and welcomed Odai as his mother.

After the Battle of Okehazama, Ieyasu became independent from the Imagawa family and allied with the Oda family, gave the family name Matsudaira to the three sons of Toshikatsu HISAMATSU and Odai, made them his retainers, and welcomed Odai as his mother.

After the Battle of Okehazama, Ieyasu became independent from the Imagawa family and allied with the Oda family, gave the family name Matsudaira to the three sons of Toshikatsu HISAMATSU and Odai, made them his retainers, and welcomed Odai as his mother.

sen.j: 於大は夫・久松俊勝の死後、剃髪して伝通院と号す。
sen.e: Odai took the tonsure and called herself Denzyuin after the death of her husband, Toshikatsu HISAMATSU.
Odai underwent tonsure and called herself Denzuuin after the death of her husband, Toshikatsu HISAMATSU.
Odai underwent tonsure and called herself Denzuin after the death of her husband, Toshikatsu HISAMATSU.

sen.j: 関ヶ原の戦いの後の1602年には、秀吉未亡人・高台院や後陽成天皇に拝謁し、豊国神社 (京都市)に詣でて徳川氏が豊臣氏に敵意がないことを示した。
sen.e: In 1602, after the Battle of Sekigahara, she had an audience with the widow of Hideyoshi, Kodaiin and Emperor Goyozei, and visited Toyokuni-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City) to show that the Tokugawa clan had no hostility toward the Toyotomi clan.

In 1602, after the Battle of Sekigahara, she had an audience with the widow of Hideyoshi, Kodaiin and Emperor Goyozei, and visited Toyokuni-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City) to show that the Tokugawa clan had no hostility toward the Toyotomi clan.

In 1602, after the Battle of Sekigahara, she had an audience with the widow of Hideyoshi, Kodaiin and Emperor Goyozei, and visited Toyokuni-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City) to show that the Tokugawa clan had no hostility toward the Toyotomi clan.

sen.j: 同年、家康の滞在する京都伏見城で死去。
sen.e: In the same year, she died in Fushimi-jo Castle in Kyoto, where Ieyasu stayed.
In the same year, she died in Fushimi-jo Castle in Kyoto, where Ieyasu was staying.
In the same year, she died in Fushimi-jo Castle in Kyoto, where Ieyasu was staying.

sen.j: 遺骨は江戸小石川の伝通院に埋葬された。
sen.e: Her ashes were buried in Denzyuin in Koishikawa, Edo.
Her ashes were buried at Denzuu-in Temple in Koishikawa, Edo.
Her ashes were buried at Denzu-in Temple in Koishikawa, Edo.

sen.j: 法名は傳通院殿蓉誉光岳智香大禅定尼。
sen.e: Her posthumous Buddhist name was 傳通院殿蓉誉光岳智香大禅定尼.
sen.cmt: 傳通院殿蓉誉光岳智香大禅定尼は、読み方がわかりませんでした。日本語のままにしました。
sen.e: Her posthumous Buddhist name is Denzuuinden Yoyokogaku Chiko Daizenjoni.
sen.cmt: was > is傳通院殿蓉誉光岳智香大禅定尼 > Denzuuinden Yoyokogaku Chiko Daizenjoni(でんづういんでん ようよこうがく ちこう だいぜんじょうに)
sen.e: Her posthumous Buddhist name is Denzuinden Yoyokogaku Chiko Daizenjoni.

sen.j: 彼女の菩提寺は各地に建てられた。
sen.e: Her family temples were built in various locations.
Her family temples were built in various locations.
Her family temples were built in various locations.

sen.j: 於大の出生地・東浦町は彼女を記念して緒川の地に「於大公園」を整備し、毎年「於大まつり」を催している。
sen.e: Higashiuracho, where Odai was born, built the 'Odai Park' in Ogawa in her memory and hold 'Odai festivals' every year.
Odai's birthplace of Higashiura-cho constructed 'Odai Park' in Ogawa in her memory and holds an 'Odai Festivals' every year.
Odai's birthplace of Higashiura-cho constructed 'Odai Park' in Ogawa in her memory and holds an 'Odai Festivals' every year.

sen.e: Wife of Tadamasa MATSUDAIRA (later remarried Tadayoshi MATSUDAIRA (Sakurai MATSUDAIRA family) (real brother Tadamasa) Masanao Hoshina)
